column2: Mistress Mary, quite contrary, How does your garden grow? With dingle bells and cockle shells And cowslips, all in a row.
column3: Mistress Mary, quite contrary, How does your garden grow? With dingle bells and cockle shells And cowslips, all in a row.

column2: High upon a cliff that overlooked the sea was a little white cottage, in which dwelt a sailor and his wife, with their two strong sons and a little girl.
column3: High upon a cliff that overlooked the sea was a little white cottage, in which dwelt a sailor and his wife, with their two strong sons and a little girl.

column2: The sons were also sailors, and had made several voyages with their father in a pretty ship called the "Skylark." Their names were Hobart and Robart.
column3: The sons were also sailors, and had made several voyages with their father in a pretty ship called the "Skylark." Their names were Hobart and Robart.

column2: The little girl's name was Mary, and she was very happy indeed when her father and her brothers were at home, for they petted her and played games with her and loved her very dearly But when the "Skylark" went to sea, and her mother and herself were left alone in the little white cottage, the hours were very dull and tedious, and Mary counted the days until the sailors came home again.
column3: The little girl's name was Mary, and she was very happy indeed when her father and her brothers were at home, for they petted her and played games with her and loved her very dearly But when the "Skylark" went to sea, and her mother and herself were left alone in the little white cottage, the hours were very dull and tedious, and Mary counted the days until the sailors came home again.

column2: One spring, just as the grasses began to grow green upon the cliff and the trees were dressing their stiff, barren branches in robes of delicate foliage, the father and brothers bade good-bye to Mary and her mother, for they were starting upon a voyage to the Black Sea.
column3: One spring, just as the grasses began to grow green upon the cliff and the trees were dressing their stiff, barren branches in robes of delicate foliage, the father and brothers bade good bye to Mary and her mother, for they were starting upon a voyage to the Black Sea.

column2: And how long will you be gone, papa? asked Mary, who was perched upon her father's knee, where she could nestle her soft cheek against his bushy whiskers.
column3: And how long will you be gone, papa? asked Mary, who was perched upon her father's knee, where she could nestle her soft cheek against his bushy whiskers.

column2: How long? he repeated, stroking her curls tenderly as he spoke; "well, well, my darling, it will be a long time indeed!
column3: How long? he repeated, stroking her curls tenderly as he spoke; "well, well, my darling, it will be a long time indeed!

column2: Do you know the cowslips that grow in the pastures, Mary?"
column3: Do you know the cowslips that grow in the pastures, Mary?"

column2: Oh, yes; I watch for them every spring, she answered.
column3: Oh, yes; I watch for them every spring, she answered.

column2: And do you know the dingle-bells that grow near the edge of the wood? he asked again.
column3: And do you know the dingle bells that grow near the edge of the wood? he asked again.

column2: I know them well, papa, replied Mary, "for often I gather their blue blossoms and put them in a vase upon the table."
column3: I know them well, papa, replied Mary, "for often I gather their blue blossoms and put them in a vase upon the table."

column2: And how about the cockle-shells?
column3: And how about the cockle shells?

column2: Them also I know, said Mary eagerly, for she was glad her father should find her so well acquainted with the field flowers; "there is nothing prettier than the big white flowers of the cockle-shells.
column3: Them also I know, said Mary eagerly, for she was glad her father should find her so well acquainted with the field flowers; "there is nothing prettier than the big white flowers of the cockle shells.

column2: But tell me, papa, what have the flowers to do with your coming home?"
column3: But tell me, papa, what have the flowers to do with your coming home?"

column2: Why, just this, sweetheart, returned the sailor gravely; "all the time that it takes the cowslips and dingle-bells and cockle-shells to sprout from the ground, and grow big and strong, and blossom into flower, and, yes--to wither and die away again--all that time shall your brothers and I sail the seas.
column3: Why, just this, sweetheart, returned the sailor gravely; "all the time that it takes the cowslips and dingle bells and cockle shells to sprout from the ground, and grow big and strong, and blossom into flower, and, yes-to wither and die away again-all that time shall your brothers and I sail the seas.

column2: But when the cold winds begin to blow, and the flowers are gone, then, God willing, we shall come back to you; and by that time you may have grown wiser and bigger, and I am sure you will have grown older.
column3: But when the cold winds begin to blow, and the flowers are gone, then, God willing, we shall come back to you; and by that time you may have grown wiser and bigger, and I am sure you will have grown older.

column2: So one more kiss, sweetheart, and then we must go, for our time is up."
column3: So one more kiss, sweetheart, and then we must go, for our time is up."

column2: The next morning, when Mary and her mother had dried their eyes, which had been wet with grief at the departure of their loved ones, the little girl asked earnestly,
column3: The next morning, when Mary and her mother had dried their eyes, which had been wet with grief at the departure of their loved ones, the little girl asked earnestly,

column2: Mamma, may I make a flower-garden?
column3: Mamma, may I make a flower garden?

column2: A flower-garden! repeated her mother in surprise; "why do you wish a flower-garden, Mary?"
column3: A flower garden! repeated her mother in surprise; "why do you wish a flower garden, Mary?"

column2: I want to plant in it the cockle-shells and the cowslips and the dingle-bells, she answered.
column3: I want to plant in it the cockle shells and the cowslips and the dingle bells, she answered.

column2: And her mother, who had heard what the sailor had said to his little girl, knew at once what Mary meant; so she kissed her daughter and replied,
column3: And her mother, who had heard what the sailor had said to his little girl, knew at once what Mary meant; so she kissed her daughter and replied,

column2: Yes, Mary, you may have the flower-garden, if you wish.	Yes, Mary, you may have the flower garden, if you wish.
column3: true

column2: We will dig a nice little bed just at the side of the house, and you shall plant your flowers and care for them yourself."
column3: We will dig a nice little bed just at the side of the house, and you shall plant your flowers and care for them yourself."

column2: I think I 'd rather have the flowers at the front of the house, said Mary.
column3: I think I 'd rather have the flowers at the front of the house, said Mary.

column2: But why? enquired her mother; "they will be better sheltered at the side."
column3: But why? enquired her mother; "they will be better sheltered at the side."

column2: I want them in front, persisted Mary, "for the sun shines stronger there."
column3: I want them in front, persisted Mary, "for the sun shines stronger there."

column2: Very well, answered her mother, "make your garden at the front, if you will, and I will help you to dig up the ground."
column3: Very well, answered her mother, "make your garden at the front, if you will, and I will help you to dig up the ground."

column2: But I do n't want you to help, said Mary, "for this is to be my own little flower-garden, and I want to do all the work myself."
column3: But I do n't want you to help, said Mary, "for this is to be my own little flower garden, and I want to do all the work myself."

column2: Now I must tell you that this little girl, although very sweet in many ways, had one serious fault.
column3: Now I must tell you that this little girl, although very sweet in many ways, had one serious fault.

column2: She was inclined to be a bit contrary, and put her own opinions and ideas before those of her elders.
column3: She was inclined to be a bit contrary, and put her own opinions and ideas before those of her elders.

column2: Perhaps Mary meant no wrong in this; she often thought knew better how to do a thing than others did; and in such a case she was not only contrary, but anxious to have her own way.
column3: Perhaps Mary meant no wrong in this; she often thought knew better how to do a thing than others did; and in such a case she was not only contrary, but anxious to have her own way.

column2: And so her mother, who did not like her little daughter to be unhappy, often gave way to her in small things, and now she permitted Mary to make her own garden, and plant it as she would.
column3: And so her mother, who did not like her little daughter to be unhappy, often gave way to her in small things, and now she permitted Mary to make her own garden, and plant it as she would.

column2: So Mary made a long, narrow bed at the front of the house, and then she prepared to plant her flowers.
column3: So Mary made a long, narrow bed at the front of the house, and then she prepared to plant her flowers.

column2: If you scatter the seeds, said her mother, "the flower-bed will look very pretty."
column3: If you scatter the seeds, said her mother, "the flower bed will look very pretty."

column2: Now this was what Mary was about to do; but since her mother advised it, she tried to think of another way, for, as I said, she was contrary at times.
column3: Now this was what Mary was about to do; but since her mother advised it, she tried to think of another way, for, as I said, she was contrary at times.

column2: And in the end she planted the dingle-bells all in one straight row, and the cockle-shells in another straight row the length of the bed, and she finished by planting the cowslips in another long row at the back.
column3: And in the end she planted the dingle bells all in one straight row, and the cockle shells in another straight row the length of the bed, and she finished by planting the cowslips in another long row at the back.

column2: Her mother smiled, but said nothing; and now, as the days passed by, Mary watered and tended her garden with great care; and when the flowers began to sprout she plucked all the weeds that grew among them, and so in the mild spring weather the plants grew finely.
column3: Her mother smiled, but said nothing; and now, as the days passed by, Mary watered and tended her garden with great care; and when the flowers began to sprout she plucked all the weeds that grew among them, and so in the mild spring weather the plants grew finely.

column2: When they have grown up big and strong, said Mary one morning, as she weeded the bed, "and when they have budded and blossomed and faded away again, then papa and my brothers will come home.
column3: When they have grown up big and strong, said Mary one morning, as she weeded the bed, "and when they have budded and blossomed and faded away again, then papa and my brothers will come home.

column2: And I shall call the cockle-shells papa, for they are the biggest and strongest; and the dingle-bells shall be brother Hobart, and the cowslips brother Robart.
column3: And I shall call the cockle shells papa, for they are the biggest and strongest; and the dingle bells shall be brother Hobart, and the cowslips brother Robart.

column2: And now I feel as if the flowers were really my dear ones, and I must be very careful that they come to no harm!"
column3: And now I feel as if the flowers were really my dear ones, and I must be very careful that they come to no harm!"

column3: She was filled with joy when one morning she ran out to her flower garden after breakfast and found the dingle bells and cowslips were actually blossoming, while even the cockle shells were showing their white buds.

column2: They looked rather comical, all standing in stiff, straight rows, one after the other; but Mary did not mind that.

column2: While she was working she heard the tramp of a horse's hoofs, and looking up saw the big bluff Squire riding toward her.
column3: While she was working she heard the tramp of a horse's hoofs, and looking up saw the big bluff Squire riding toward her.

column2: The big Squire was very fond of children, and whenever he rode near the little white cottage he stopped to have a word with Mary.
column3: The big Squire was very fond of children, and whenever he rode near the little white cottage he stopped to have a word with Mary.

column2: He was old and bald-headed, and he had side-whiskers that were very red in color and very short and stubby; but there was ever a merry twinkle in his blue eyes, and Mary well knew him for her friend.
column3: He was old and bald headed, and he had side whiskers that were very red in color and very short and stubby; but there was ever a merry twinkle in his blue eyes, and Mary well knew him for her friend.

column3: Now, when she looked up and saw him coming toward her flower garden, she nodded and smiled to him, and the big bluff Squire rode up to her side, and looked down with a smile at her flowers.

column2: Because I watched the flowers; and the dingle-bells and cowslips and cockle-shells are all withered and faded away.	Because I watched the flowers; and the dingle bells and cowslips and cockle shells are all withered and faded away.

column2: And did you not say that, God willing, when this happened you would come back to us?"
column3: And did you not say that, God willing, when this happened you would come back to us?"

column2: To be sure I did, answered her father, with a happy laugh; "and I must have spoken truly, sweetheart, for God in His goodness was willing, and here I am!"
column3: To be sure I did, answered her father, with a happy laugh; "and I must have spoken truly, sweetheart, for God in His goodness was willing, and here I am!"

column2: The Wond'rous Wise Man
column3: The Wond'rous Wise Man

column2: The Wond'rous Wise Man
column3: The Wond'rous Wise Man

column2: There was a man in our town And he was wond'rous wise; He jumped into a bramble bush And scratched out both his eyes. And when he saw his eyes were out, With all his might and main He jumped into another bush And scratched them in again!
column3: There was a man in our town And he was wond'rous wise; He jumped into a bramble bush And scratched out both his eyes. And when he saw his eyes were out, With all his might and main He jumped into another bush And scratched them in again!
